job_title: Career Coach Graduate Assistant in Austin, TX
pros: Being a graduate assistant allowed me to develop so many skills I would need before I began full-time work.
cons: Salary is very little for being a graduate assistant, but at least tuition is waived.

review_title: They’ve got about 4 years left before closure
pros: Beautiful campus in the hill country.
cons: Campus is not designed for a college, very inaccessible. Executive team is a mess. They prioritize hiring employees who buy into the “mission” (which is a joke) over those with actual knowledge and skill. If they mistakenly hire someone with skill, they will let them go very quickly once that person begins to question poor, unethical practices. Pay is atrocious. They re-org constantly. I personally know of over 25 people who have been let go in the last 3 years. For a small campus, that is a lot. They are bleeding money and do not have the student population to sustain staying open - especially since building a multimillion dorm. The clock is ticking on it’s collapse.

pros: Great people to work with. Good benefits. Meaningful mission.
cons: Going through a lot of transition. Lack of career mobility. Employee retention.

pros: Fellow professors and most of the students make me stay. Lovely campus nestled in the hill country.
cons: Faculty are overworked, underpaid and constant reorganizations. Faculty are not respected unless part of the favored few. Lack of shared governance structure, frequent firings, and the smart ones are pushed out or just leave.

review_title: There needs to be a ZERO star rating for it
pros: nice campus, some nice folks
cons: poor management, no adherence to its core values, constant reorganizations and layoffs, below poverty wages, age discrimination

pros: Can put on resume Lenient hours You can choose what classes you tutor
cons: Students can be hard to teach sometimes Might not always get work

pros: Great organization to work for.

pros: Amazing community - lots of growth

pros: The mission of serving students is invigorating. People here truly have a heart for students.
cons: Some departments are understaffed. Since the university is smaller, there are often just one or two people for each function.

pros: Wide range of experiences, great exposure to biological and chemical labs, lots of opportunities for responsibility

job_title: Student Writing Center Tutor in Austin, TX
pros: I really loved being a student at CTX and working for them
cons: They could not keep me on after graduation

pros: My personal experience at has been a very positive one. I began working at Concordia in the middle of adulthood. My supervisors have been outstanding - highly ethical, professional, service-oriented, and open to new ideas and ways of doing things. No place is perfect, but the majority of the people are authentically caring and highly committed to the students and each other. My family and I love living in Austin, and we have no desire to move to another place. Concordia has provided what we have needed in this season of our lives - the stability of remaining in the city we love, where we already have a support system of friends, family and church. Also, it has provided schedule flexibility as we have experienced more demands and growing responsibilities in our family. Above everything else, working at a place that positively impacts the lives of students has been very rewarding. The pay is moderate, but the factors mentioned above have been more than enough for me to choose to remain here for more than 6 years.
cons: It's a small, non-profit university so you often have to wear many hats and be involved in doing a lot of different things. This can be demanding at times, but it can be good in some ways also. It has required me to learn a lot, which has been tough and yet rewarding.

job_title: Nursing Student RN in Austin, TX
pros: The hybrid program is only 16 months.
cons: Modifications to the program due to covid.

pros: Most departments allow you to be independent and allow for a flexible working schedule, but that does not ring true across the organization so you don't know who will allow you to have a flex schedule or not. In general it feels very much like a family, but lately with the organizational changes it feels less so.
cons: The recent changes in leadership have shaken up the university, but remains to be seen if these are positive or not. I'm afraid that people are being put into power because of connections instead of job fit. I hope this doesn't have a negative effect on the university's goals. Most positions are highly under paid as well. Even when promises of compensation evaluations are done, the employees don't see positive results.

pros:
It is a nice looking campus
At least there are some people that are friendly and authentic
cons:
There are many double standards
They talk about being diverse and support inclusion, but it is all masked and mired by "Christian" values.  If you are not Christian, live alternative lifestyles, or are anywhere close to different than the status quo then good luck keeping your job during "reorganization" time.  Their marketing material is designed to deceive students and prospective jobholders. Students and staff cannot be authentic unless you really buy into the all-out strict Lutheran lifestyle. You are either Christian or "pre-Christian". Yes, I understand it is a Christian institution but there are so many other universities that are also Christian that are accepting of people of all backgrounds.
There is high turnover and terminations happen often
Pay is a joke

pros: The campus is really beautiful.  The people are friendly.
cons: Huge staff turnover.  New executives are very inexperienced and fight among themselves. Poor financial forecast for the next several years. Criteria for being promoted is to be a yes man to the president and be LCMS. Talent is leaving the minute they can   Benefits and positions are being cut while top execs are paid more. Execs not interested in others' opinion. Atmosphere of secrecy and no plan to turn things around other than to cut what is already a lean operation. Unwilling to admit what is wrong and take responsibility. Promotes and hires not on expertise but on religious affiliation and good ole boy system. Remaining staff end up having to work more for less. No trust and entrenched silos.

pros: There were not too many pros to speak of. The campus is nice at times, however, there are a lot of issues with it. I had a nice supervisor.
cons:
The entire university is corrupt from the top CEO down. Their unethical and unlawful practices are disheartening. They are extremely hypocritical and if you wish to work fro an employer that exhibits these practices then this is the place for you. They make up policies that fit what they want to do. If they like you they'll keep you no matter how much work you do.
If you are a hard worker desiring to excel, lead, and develop yourselves then this isn't the place for you. If you want to do as little as possible but please the upper management to get ahead then this is the place for you.

pros: If you are LCMS *and* you don't really care about professional development, this might be the place for you.
cons:
How much space is there?
1) You must sign a morality clause that says you can't cohabitate, be gay, or deviate in any way from the teachings of the LCMS church.  Could be a Pro for some, I don't know.
2) Depending on the department, you will get no professional development or training.  In fact, you may find yourself within months of hire doing something completely different than what you were hired to do.  It is completely demotivating.
3) HR is mired in payroll and accounting activities; they will not be much help to you!!
4) Pay is generally below market and cost of living increases have been frozen for two years due to "budget issues".
5) Innovation and progressive thinking is not encouraged or rewarded.  Other than a free (mediocre) degree, I'm not sure why anyone would want to work here.
6) It's in freaking Cedar Park!

review_title: How can they keep going like this?
pros: New softball field, campus clean, pretty background.
cons: The spirit is dead. How can faculty reflect a great teaching atmosphere for students when there is zero cohesiveness? This place needs an entire shift. Students are being ripped off by this campus with no infirmary, not enough dorms, a tacky gym compared to other universities, no bus route or any sort of public transportation and a dangerous highway to cross over if you don't have a vehicle. The campus is Christian, yet there is no pastoral staff hired just to minister to students. All the pastors are Religion teachers hiding in their offices.

pros: I was told in the interview that I’d wear many hats and to expect my work to be challenging and rewarding. It’s been everything I expected and more. I’ve seen several people mention changing environment and the need for versatility as if it were a bad thing. I think most not for profit organizations operate in a manner wherein this is the norm. Additionally, one can traditionally expect pay to be lower in these type markets. I work here because I love the people and the atmosphere. Each day I know I make a difference.
cons: I truly enjoy where I work.

pros: Concordia is full of friendly, hardworking employees who get recognized for their achievements and are made to feel appreciated by all levels of the University.  Benefits are great and pay is  excellent compared to other similar organizations.  I'm sure you could make more in private industry but that's not where I want to be.  I love the campus and feel appreciated for my contributions.
cons: After about a year in my job, I haven't seen any.  I look forward to going to work every day.

review_title: One of Austin's best places to work
pros: It's like working in Sherwood Forrest .  The campus is located in a wildlife nature preserve so we are surrounded by trees and watch birds, squirrels, rabbits, even caught an occasional glimpse of a family of foxes from our office windows.  It's a pretty and peaceful setting in which to work.  Low stress environment even during busy times of the semester.  Working in a Christian environment is an extra blessing.
cons: Salaries are on the low end.

pros: The university gives their employees great health benefits and the campus is beautiful. Also, employees/spouses/children can get free tuition on undergraduate and graduate classes. If you already have a graduate degree you can potentially teach a class in your field.
cons: There is little opportunity for advancement and professional development. Also the salaries are not very competitive. In some departments there is a poor work-life balance because there are not enough people to do the work.

review_title: Great people to work alongside, but the talent retention and long-term planning leaves something to be desired.
pros: It was a work environment that encouraged collaboration and close relationships. People who worked together cared about each other.
cons: Little incentive to innovate or try new things, since it never resulted in raises or any kind of meaningful recognition.

pros:
Great culture with respect to interpersonal environment 
Genuine appreciation for employee well being
Team Collaboration within departments 
Opportunity exists for institutional improvement laterally and vertically
cons:
Double Standards
High expectations with minimal relevant resources 
Lack of accountability (scapegoat mentality) 
Overly process oriented to a detriment

pros: Concordia has wonderful people who want to make the University successful.  The desire is there to make it great and the executives seem committed to that goal as well.
cons: Pay is lower than most places, no room to advance and favoritism is prevalent throughout the University.

review_title: Christian values mean nothing to them when it comes to staff loyalty
pros: Beautiful campus.  Staff ready to serve.
cons: Revolving door.  Quality employees are let go for no good reason.  Always looking to cut administrative costs by way of 'reorganization." Tout Christian values, but have no loyalty to their employees.  Everyone is dispensable based on bottom line.

review_title: No Mission No Results No Good - All Politics
pros: Good people working there....mainly for the tuition benefits or faculty schedule.
cons:
Everything else.  This university is a joke.  There are some educators that truly care, however the majority of the classes are taught by adjuncts and the curriculum is sub par to say the least.  NO ONE fails out of Concordia.  
The Culture is one of avoidance. Staff/Faculty are not developed, there is no investment in time, consideration, or respect given to those who work here.   The executive team meets all the time and there are never results.  Folks are fired and never advised of the deficiencies or given a chance to be better.  No one is ever held to higher standards.  The Chief Advancement Officer hasn't raised any money or built the endowment since she arrived (someone did die and leave the school some money), however still has a job.  The Chief Enrollment Officer has dwindling enrollment year over year for 5 years and still has a job.  The President got his PHD  online and has never run a University, the Provost and the CFO are the only people who really work for results and everyone talks badly about them because they won't go with the flow of mediocrity.  This is not a good place to work, nor a good school to be a part of if you want your student/child to be challenged and more prepared for the world.  There are good faculty, and some good lower level workers who work not for the money (because there is none).  The remainder work there because they don't have to work hard and have a relaxed no accountability environment.

pros: The culture is a product of the university's commitment, and the employees' buy in, to the mission and it fosters success.  Beautiful campus.
cons: Pay is low. Expect to tradeoff salary expectations for the great benefits including tuition waiver for you and your family and the satisfaction from your contributions to a wonderful community working together toward common goals.

pros: Flexible schedule, beautiful location, and most people are very nice. Benefits are  good.
cons: Low pay, high burnout, and constantly reorganizations within the university. Culture can tough for some departments. High turnover in key departments due to  poor supervisors/pay.

pros: The people are friendly and the environment is Christian. Very good work/life balance.
cons: The internal direction is not clear and they need to work on communicating that to all employees.

pros: Administration and faculty tend to get along quite well. The student body seems to genuinely care
cons: Low pay for the expected amount of work. Little to no incentive for extra work

job_title: Help Desk Technician in Austin, TX
pros: Friendly environment, helpful peers, understanding supervisors, dedicated, professional.
cons: The pay isn't all that great

pros: My boss and director were very nice and helpful
cons: This position was nothing like they had sold me on originally. The admissions team is rude and unprofessional. The place needs to get organized and adapt a sense of urgency.

pros: Location is lovely and certain departments are not as bad as others.
cons: Bad management with a hierarchy that is in stone and resistant to change or improvement.

pros: Very close community, great company to work for.
cons: Sometimes communication can be better internally

review_title: From teacher to tech geek. Couldn't be happier.
pros:
I am relieved to move from teaching in public schools (where innovation is often resisted or actively discouraged) to the start up world where it is valued ant encouraged. Great people, AMAZING mission statement and people actually believe it: Education is a Human Right. 
Lastly, every Friday there is a chance to celebrate successes and share visions for our product. I feel that all ideas are embraced and visionary goals are welcome.
cons: I read some of the other reviews. I must say that my interactions with leadership have all been very positive. Sometimes it is difficult to quantify innovation, so being flexible and adaptable is essential. It is true that this is more than a 9-5 clock in/out job, so if you don't really believe in the vision, you may feel strained.

review_title: Lovely people, lovely office, but there's something amiss when everyone is grumbling...
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
Great snacks in the kitchen.
Really great coworkers to work with. 
Serving a well intentioned purpose - spreading education worldwide.
Pretty office. Standing desk area is cute.
You can tell people are passionate about what the company does-- though maybe not so much what they do for the company.
cons:
No real space for advancement.
Everyone starts on a 3 month fellowship (less pay + benefits) during which you're told you may be let go if you don't work hard enough, meaning you pretty much work yourself to the bone. If you're a workaholic, that's great, but people here are obviously stressed and burnt out. The social environment is really bizarre because new people aren't really formally introduced to everyone else. You can walk around for weeks wondering who that "new guy" is. There are no forms of real socializing/in-office-networking events, so you always feel like all your coworkers are strangers, except for the ones who sit near you. 
Also sickness seems to spread really quickly around this office, maybe because people can't afford to take a sick day what with the policies.
Policies - Gooru is a startup that's quite new so of course it didn't set its policies right away, but the problem is that they "set" them and would let people know but then they would "change" them again, which wreaked havoc on some people's plans. 

Basically, when I look around, I see unhappy, overworked employees. The turnover rate is extremely high, and for good reason. I've spoken with a substantial number of the employees about their discomfort with the way the company is run, but they stay for other reasons (until they leave in a few months, of course).

review_title: Get good experience and get out

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
- Great Mission
- Snacks
- Work with schools is rewarding
- 401k match for upto $2k
- Health Insurance
cons:
- CEO does not care about employees
- CEO is dishonest with employees, customers, and teachers/students
- CEO has very inappropriate infatuation with certain employees
- CEO constantly lies to board about usage numbers, clients in Board Meetings. When we had our first signed client, and he told the board, one member of the board asked to be shown the signed physical contract just to make sure he was not lying.
- CEO has run this company to the ground.

Please consider this and the 10+ other negative reviews before even thinking about applying to Gooru.

review_title: Its worse than it looks, think hard about working here.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros: some wonderful super sharp colleagues, great technology, plenty of real student programs in districts using the product. Great opportunities to connect with organizations and changemakers at the top of the field.
cons:
These are the things that make it hard to work at Gooru: 

The CEO is a boss, not a leader. A classic industrial revolution style boss. As with most of this set, he is threatened rather than empowered by talent. He relies on a rapid churn cycle of people he learns to emulate and then treats as worthless. He refers frequently to  Gooru’s “execution bias,” a focus on data-driven action. Problematically, in practice this execution bias is impulse-driven, informed by his waxing and waning moods and whatever odd conversation he has with someone in the field on a given day. Process improvements put in place by the dedicated team are often turned on their head based on his eureka moments, only to revert entirely a week later. Real data on how things are going, such as the insights gathered here, are considered irrelevant. 

He prefers to hire young workers directly out of college who are unfamiliar with healthy work environments and can function as pupils. The current strategy is to hire as few senior people and education specialists as possible, rather have them consult on an hourly basis at arms length where they see little of the internal strife and won’t cry foul. Disclaimer: this strategy may have changed 5 times since I've written this. 

Raising a red flag about how things are going is considered taboo and often punished rapidly. You are likely to be shamed within 24 hours, lose responsibilities, and receive blank stares from the knowing eyes of colleagues too intimidated to confirm the elephants in the room. Those who know how to play the game do ok. The trust level across teams is very low with high levels of internal competition that seem misplaced in a nonprofit context.

Much has been said in these reviews about the existing leadership structure. The organization has a two-person leadership team that co-creates key performance indicators with a faux leadership team designed to look like they are an extension of said team.As has been indicated by many, the second in command has little education expertise and is universally regarded as poorly suited to her position. A mass human resources exodus now counting over 40 in less than 3 years is their joint legacy. 

It is difficult to claim you are honoring the human right to education in an institution that’s built on a core of distrust and a foundation of manipulation.  This organization is resurrecting the darkest corners of the past its product so hopes to reform.

review_title: Overall a rough experience. Went in with high hopes and left without much direction in terms of my personal career.
job_title: Content Producer in San Francisco, CA
pros: You're able to meet a wide variety of dynamic individuals from a variety of backgrounds.
cons: Leadership is ineffective, lack of an overall vision and growth is minimal.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palo Alto, CA
pros:
-Free lunch(Do not know if that is still being continued as there were talks about stopping it)
-Loaded kitchen
cons:
-I worked here for more than 6 months and realized that the company is on a downward trajectory.
-Terrible work-life balance;Employees are expected to put their noses to the grindstone 24*7. Further, employees are not-recognized for their hard work. The current employees have been institutionalized. Instead of finding a solution, their idea is to subtly convey this message to prospective employees through their career page so as to prepare them for their impending doom.
-Discussions that happen during meetings go into a black-hole. I have been a part of many meetings where there have been talks about establishing a culture, improving benefits for employees, bringing in new talent etc but have not seen any of these being incorporated anytime. 
-New employees realize what they have gotten themselves into and resign soon. There has been a major attrition in the company and it has now been reduced to merely 10-14 people slogging it out.
-Employees are underpaid. They try to get away with most things under the garb of 'non-profit'. Their main 'mission' is to outsource work to other cheaper countries, make them slog while the employees in the US criticize them and load them with more issues and bugs.

pros:
